rev.comment: rm addition of non-free media, lacking rationale, and replaceable as the subject is alive.
rev.diff:
Line 42: Line 42:
Whilst still in the touring production of ''Miss Saigon'', Ellis rehearsed for four weeks in order to play her next lead role, [[Fantine]], a Parisian grisette, in ''[[Les MisÃ©rables (musical)|Les MisÃ©rables]]''. She named Fantine "a role [she] always wanted to play" because she "grew up singing" the musical score.<ref name="personal" /> She began performing the role on June 27, 2005 at the [[Queen's Theatre]] in London and played Fantine for almost a year. She ended her time with the company on June 24, 2006, again, in pursuance of a new leading West End role.
Whilst still in the touring production of ''Miss Saigon'', Ellis rehearsed for four weeks in order to play her next lead role, [[Fantine]], a Parisian grisette, in ''[[Les MisÃ©rables (musical)|Les MisÃ©rables]]''. She named Fantine "a role [she] always wanted to play" because she "grew up singing" the musical score.<ref name="personal" /> She began performing the role on June 27, 2005 at the [[Queen's Theatre]] in London and played Fantine for almost a year. She ended her time with the company on June 24, 2006, again, in pursuance of a new leading West End role.
â
[[File:Picture22-med.jpg|thumb|left|Kerry Ellis ([[Elphaba]]) and [[Dianne Pilkington]] ([[Glinda]]) in the 2007 London production of the musical, ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]''.]]In 2006, Ellis joined the original London cast of the new musical, ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'', to play [[Elphaba]], serving as a temporary standby to [[Idina Menzel]], who originated the lead role on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. Subsequently, she played the role on nine occasions in Menzel's absence<ref>{{Cite web|title=...Kerry had the chance to perform nine times in the lead role|url=http://www.wickeduk.co.uk/odc/index.php?id=kerryellis|work=WickedUK.co.uk}}</ref> before taking over the full-time position in the role of Elphaba after Menzel's pre-planned departure three months after the show had opened on January 1, 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|title=On New Year's Day the actress takes over from Idina Menzel as Elphaba...|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-424290/Shes-wicked-nasty.html|work=The Daily Mail|location=London}}</ref> For this role, she won "Best Takeover in a Role" at the 2008 Theatregoer's Choice Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Other winners include ... Kerry Ellis (Best Takeover in a Role for Wicked)|url=http://awards.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=471|work=WhatsOnStage.com}}</ref> She would play the role in London until June 7, 2008, when she temporarily departed the Apollo Victoria, to be succeeded by [[Alexia Khadime]],<ref>{{Cite web|title=Alexia Khadime ... will play Elphaba in Wicked...|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821207071697|work=WhatsOnStage.com}}</ref> and transferred to the Broadway production of ''Wicked'' at the [[Gershwin Theatre]] with performances starting from June 17, 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|title=...ten days after her final performance in London on June 7, she will play Elphaba in the Broadway production at the Gershwin Theatre|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-547937/Wicked-witch-Kerry-Ellis-magic-touch.html|work=The Daily Mail|location=London}}</ref> She replaced stage actress, [[Stephanie J. Block]], on Broadway, making her not only the first British actress to play the role of Elphaba, but also the first to transfer from the West End to Broadway,<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ellis ... is the first British actress to play Elphaba...|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/115331-Londons-Kerry-Ellis-Will-Join-Broadways-Wicked-in-June|work=Playbill.com}}</ref> mirroring original Broadway cast member Idina Menzel who transferred from Broadway to London to open the production. For her run in the Broadway production, she won the 2009 Broadway.com Audience Award for "Favorite Female Breakthrough Performance".<ref>{{Cite web|title=...2009 Broadway.com Audience Award winners announced|url=http://www.broadway.com/shows/wicked/buzz/98556/the-fans-have-spoken-2009-broadwaycom-audience-award-winners-announced/|work=Broadway.com}}</ref> Ellis left the Broadway company on November 9, 2008 and was replaced by [[Marcie Dodd]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Kerry Ellis ... played ... final performance November 9|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/123159-Broadways-Wicked-Welcomes-Dodd-Mauzey-Kern-and-OMalley-Nov-11|work=Playbill.com}}</ref>
+
In 2006, Ellis joined the original London cast of the new musical, ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'', to play [[Elphaba]], serving as a temporary standby to [[Idina Menzel]], who originated the lead role on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. Subsequently, she played the role on nine occasions in Menzel's absence<ref>{{Cite web|title=...Kerry had the chance to perform nine times in the lead role|url=http://www.wickeduk.co.uk/odc/index.php?id=kerryellis|work=WickedUK.co.uk}}</ref> before taking over the full-time position in the role of Elphaba after Menzel's pre-planned departure three months after the show had opened on January 1, 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|title=On New Year's Day the actress takes over from Idina Menzel as Elphaba...|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-424290/Shes-wicked-nasty.html|work=The Daily Mail|location=London}}</ref> For this role, she won "Best Takeover in a Role" at the 2008 Theatregoer's Choice Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Other winners include ... Kerry Ellis (Best Takeover in a Role for Wicked)|url=http://awards.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=471|work=WhatsOnStage.com}}</ref> She would play the role in London until June 7, 2008, when she temporarily departed the Apollo Victoria, to be succeeded by [[Alexia Khadime]],<ref>{{Cite web|title=Alexia Khadime ... will play Elphaba in Wicked...|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821207071697|work=WhatsOnStage.com}}</ref> and transferred to the Broadway production of ''Wicked'' at the [[Gershwin Theatre]] with performances starting from June 17, 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|title=...ten days after her final performance in London on June 7, she will play Elphaba in the Broadway production at the Gershwin Theatre|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-547937/Wicked-witch-Kerry-Ellis-magic-touch.html|work=The Daily Mail|location=London}}</ref> She replaced stage actress, [[Stephanie J. Block]], on Broadway, making her not only the first British actress to play the role of Elphaba, but also the first to transfer from the West End to Broadway,<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ellis ... is the first British actress to play Elphaba...|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/115331-Londons-Kerry-Ellis-Will-Join-Broadways-Wicked-in-June|work=Playbill.com}}</ref> mirroring original Broadway cast member Idina Menzel who transferred from Broadway to London to open the production. For her run in the Broadway production, she won the 2009 Broadway.com Audience Award for "Favorite Female Breakthrough Performance".<ref>{{Cite web|title=...2009 Broadway.com Audience Award winners announced|url=http://www.broadway.com/shows/wicked/buzz/98556/the-fans-have-spoken-2009-broadwaycom-audience-award-winners-announced/|work=Broadway.com}}</ref> Ellis left the Broadway company on November 9, 2008 and was replaced by [[Marcie Dodd]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Kerry Ellis ... played ... final performance November 9|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/123159-Broadways-Wicked-Welcomes-Dodd-Mauzey-Kern-and-OMalley-Nov-11|work=Playbill.com}}</ref>
Shortly prior to her transfer from the London production to the Broadway one of ''Wicked'', in May 2008, Ellis performed alongside Idina Menzel, [[Adam Pascal]] and [[Josh Groban]], [[Clarke Peters]], [[Marti Pellow]] and [[David Bedella]] in a two-day limited engagement of ''[[Chess (musical)#Royal_Albert_Hall.2C_2008|Chess in Concert]]'', a musical by [[Tim Rice]], [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus]] and [[Benny Andersson]], at the London's [[Royal Albert Hall]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Kerry Ellis ... has been cast as Svetlana|url=http://london.broadway.com/story/id/3009412|work=Broadway.com}}</ref> She played the role of Svetlana and upon reflection, stated that to star at the Royal Albert Hall, work with an "amazing" company and sing alongside those particular cast members "was a dream come true".<ref name="personal"/> Although a relative unknown, and in a small part, Ellis was met with positive reviews for her performance. Some critics labelled her stronger than lead, Menzel, arguing that Ellis should have received the female lead.<ref>{{Cite web|title=...I wish she'd been cast as Florence|url=http://tttcritic.blogspot.com/2008/05/chess-in-concert.html|work=TTTCrtitic.blogspot.com}}</ref> This further established the rumoured rivalry between the pair, and although neither has confirmed or denied, much speculation remains.
Shortly prior to her transfer from the London production to the Broadway one of ''Wicked'', in May 2008, Ellis performed alongside Idina Menzel, [[Adam Pascal]] and [[Josh Groban]], [[Clarke Peters]], [[Marti Pellow]] and [[David Bedella]] in a two-day limited engagement of ''[[Chess (musical)#Royal_Albert_Hall.2C_2008|Chess in Concert]]'', a musical by [[Tim Rice]], [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus]] and [[Benny Andersson]], at the London's [[Royal Albert Hall]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Kerry Ellis ... has been cast as Svetlana|url=http://london.broadway.com/story/id/3009412|work=Broadway.com}}</ref> She played the role of Svetlana and upon reflection, stated that to star at the Royal Albert Hall, work with an "amazing" company and sing alongside those particular cast members "was a dream come true".<ref name="personal"/> Although a relative unknown, and in a small part, Ellis was met with positive reviews for her performance. Some critics labelled her stronger than lead, Menzel, arguing that Ellis should have received the female lead.<ref>{{Cite web|title=...I wish she'd been cast as Florence|url=http://tttcritic.blogspot.com/2008/05/chess-in-concert.html|work=TTTCrtitic.blogspot.com}}</ref> This further established the rumoured rivalry between the pair, and although neither has confirmed or denied, much speculation remains.
Line 79: Line 79:
On September 13, 2009, Ellis appeared in "Thank You for the Music", a special concert commemorating the music of [[Benny Andersson]] and [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus]] of [[ABBA]]. The concert was held in Hyde Park and broadcast live on [[BBC Radio 2]]. At the concert, she sang "You Have to Be There", from [[Benny Andersson|Andersson]] and [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus|Ulveaus]]'s new musical, ''[[Kristina frÃ¥n DuvemÃ¥la|Kristina]]''. The event also featured other big names in music, most notably [[Kylie Minogue]], and [[Benny Andersson|Benny]] and [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus|Bjorn]] themselves also performed on stage.
On September 13, 2009, Ellis appeared in "Thank You for the Music", a special concert commemorating the music of [[Benny Andersson]] and [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus]] of [[ABBA]]. The concert was held in Hyde Park and broadcast live on [[BBC Radio 2]]. At the concert, she sang "You Have to Be There", from [[Benny Andersson|Andersson]] and [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus|Ulveaus]]'s new musical, ''[[Kristina frÃ¥n DuvemÃ¥la|Kristina]]''. The event also featured other big names in music, most notably [[Kylie Minogue]], and [[Benny Andersson|Benny]] and [[BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus|Bjorn]] themselves also performed on stage.
â
[[File:Anthems cover.png|thumb|right|The artwork for Kerry Ellis' debut album ''[[Anthems (Kerry Ellis album)|Anthems]]''.]] Ellis recorded a song with [[Mazz Murray]] and Gina Murray at [[Abbey Road Studios]] in support of Breast Cancer relief. She performed the single at a one-off concert called "Women at Rock" at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London on November 1, 2009.
+
Ellis recorded a song with [[Mazz Murray]] and Gina Murray at [[Abbey Road Studios]] in support of Breast Cancer relief. She performed the single at a one-off concert called "Women at Rock" at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London on November 1, 2009.
Ellis appears on [[BBC]]'s ''[[Last Choir Standing]]'' winners, [[Only Men Aloud!]]'s, album ''Band of Brothers'', performing a rendition of [[Queen (band)|Queen]]'s "[[Somebody to Love]]" with the choir. She was a guest performer, performing this song at an [[Only Men Aloud!]] concert at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] on December 20, 2009. Ellis later joined the band on July 18, 2010, again as a guest performer at the [[Wales Millenium Centre]], singing their rendition of "[[Somebody to Love]]". This concert was recorded for [[Only Men Aloud!]]'s television show and is scheduled to be broadcast later this year. Other celebrity guests also were involved in this filming.
Ellis appears on [[BBC]]'s ''[[Last Choir Standing]]'' winners, [[Only Men Aloud!]]'s, album ''Band of Brothers'', performing a rendition of [[Queen (band)|Queen]]'s "[[Somebody to Love]]" with the choir. She was a guest performer, performing this song at an [[Only Men Aloud!]] concert at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] on December 20, 2009. Ellis later joined the band on July 18, 2010, again as a guest performer at the [[Wales Millenium Centre]], singing their rendition of "[[Somebody to Love]]". This concert was recorded for [[Only Men Aloud!]]'s television show and is scheduled to be broadcast later this year. Other celebrity guests also were involved in this filming.
